Atlas is a quick reference on a particular subject
This application is a release from a collection named Atlas. Perhaps the name is pretentious or even misleading. Is not on purpose. We really did not found a more suitable one.

Atlas is focused on facts, with reasonable amount of text and media content. It is not meant to be exhaustive but rather to be used as a quick reference on a particular subject or field. For complete reference one can visit the external sources listed in article.
Atlas is a community, open source project. Source code can be found on GitHub. Atlas articles are updated by contributors on kids (a)cademy site.
Apache License 2.0

Atlas is distributed under Apache License 2.0, the same used by Android. This basically means anyone can do anything with application and sources but no warranty from kids (a) cademy. Source code is on https://github.com/kids-cademy/

Atlas is completely free. Free of annoying ads, no misleading in-app payment, no spy-ware. Development effort is donated. It is a humble way to show gratitude to Internet community that gives us all so much.

Atlas is a collection of related articles. An article displays a particular object, focusing on facts, with a reasonable amount of text and media content.
Atlas can be used as a quick reference on a particular subject or domain, with search being its primary mean to locate articles.
There is also an index for Atlas articles, sorted alphabetically. It can be used to browse articles collection.
Atlas can be used on both mobile phones and tablets. Phones are used in portrait mode and tablets in landscape mode.
Atlas is organized into pages that can be opened using the icons. Every page has a back arrow that allow to go back to previous pages.
From cover page, that is opened at Atlas launch, go to main menu by pressing forward arrow from title bar. From main menu can go to every Atlas page.
Atlas has also an embedded server that allows to read articles from an external browser, on a large screen. See browser sync.
Atlas articles are displayed on a reader. Reader uses vertical scroll on mobile phones and horizontal on tablets.
Reader has options to go to next and previous article, to navigate to related ones or to open external resources.
Main menu page is opened from cover page and has links to all Atlas pages. There are two groups of icons: core actions and support actions.
Core Actions
Core icons are bigger. This group is the main actions group containing links to Atlas related pages.
Usually use search page to locate Atlas article but index page can be handy to browse all items from collection.
See related user guide sections for main Atlas actions.
Support Actions
Support icons group are on page bottom side and are smaller.
Support actions provides means to share and rate the Atlas.
Atlas reader displays the articles, focused on facts, with reasonable amount of text and media content. It also has links to the related articles and the external sources.
Reader\'s page is organized into sections and uses vertical scroll on mobile phones and horizontal scroll on tablets.
Although reader has different user interfaces for mobile phones and tablets, article content is the same.
On reader actions bar there are icons for:
go to search and index pages to locate another article
navigate to next and previous article from collection, in alphabetical order
enable / disable browser synchronization for article view on an external large screen
go to Atlas main menu
Search is the primary mean to locate Atlas articles. Current implementation is not comparable with Google Search but is pretty decent.

Search is performed on words and partial word searching is not supported. This is not a so much limitation because there is auto-suggestion, updated for every user input. Anyway, there still is a limitation: search does not support multiple words.
Search happens in two steps:
collects user input and suggests the relevant keywords
uses selected keyword to actually locate Atlas article
Search result page usually has more articles, sorted by relevance. Just click on desired one to open Atlas reader. If not desired article press back from reader to go back to the search result page.
From search pages, both input and results, can go to Atlas index and main menu.

Search algorithm uses a standard search index, generated at build phase, for every Atlas release. The trick is it uses different relevance for the different article entities like titles, definitions, descriptions, image captions, related names, etc. It is classified by Wikipedia as vertical search.
Atlas index is sorted alphabetically and can be used to browse entire articles collection. Every article from index has name, icon and a short excerpt from article definition.
Index page is organized into collapsible sections, grouped by first letter from article name. Sections are ordered alphabetically.
On mobile phones the index is scrolled vertically. On tables, sections are scrolled horizontally but articles from section, vertically.
Atlas index actions bar has icons for:
reverse ordering of the index sections
collapse and expand all index sections; toggle an individual section by clicking on section icon
move to search page to locate articles by other criteria than article name
go to Atlas main menu
Atlas has an embedded custom made server that allows to read articles from an external browser, on a large screen, for a group experience.
External browser is passive. It is controlled from mobile device. Article content is pushed from Atlas server to external browser.
All browsers with push technology are supported, including smart TV. Technical name for push technology is HTML5 Server-Sent Events.
To enable / disable browser synchronization open sync page from main menu or the Atlas reader. If browser synchronization is active icon is yellow.
To start browser synchronization:
press sync button to start embedded server on mobile device
copy sync address displayed on mobile device to browser address bar and load the page
To stop synchronization open sync page and just press the stop button. Since Atlas server takes care to close itself, stop operation for synchronization is optional.
In current version external browser should be in the same network as mobile device. It is not possible to synchronize with a browser from a different location.

"The Manifesto for 'No Ads' "
1. Multiplicated Content

Arguable, Internet did change the world and we all agree with that. But aggressive advertisement campaigns lead to myriad of sites specialized on content farming and applications created only for advertisement. Digital space became an immense advertising machine with poor quality and multiplicate content.
2. Old Media Days
Digital space started to resemble old days media. In fact is worse. At least there we are not forced to see the advertisement in continuum; there is 30 minutes pause.
3. Bad Quality Ads

And advertisement quality is critical. Most ads are not so appealing, some of them being downright ugly. And in most cases destroy beautifully crafted sites and applications and ruins user experience.
4. Ad Blindness

As a result users adapted and learned to avoid areas from screen covered by ads, the so called ad blindness. There are studies revealing that up to 93 % from ads remain unviewed. So little gain for business with so bad impact on user experience!
5. Ads are not Evil per se

That being said, we do not believe advertisement is evil per se. Au contraire. Good ads can help deciding and can be fun to watch. The only problem is we do not want to see ads all the time and want them separated by content.
6. Solution

The good news is it may be a solution. Create separated space dedicated for advertisement. This way user can enjoy content and when in need for new services or products, or maybe for some fun, can willingly access advertisement page.
Accessibility Mode
In a nutshell, accessibility mode is about using Atlas without touching the screen.
The Atlas should recognize a set of spoken commands, locate desired article and play it. Use aside play button for a basic sample. Need to be online.
The goal is to allow users with visual impairment to use the Atlas but is not limited to this. For example, accessibility mode can be used by a driver while he is on the road.
Or perhaps somebody wants to improve his listening skills in a foreign language. Or simply because one is too lazy to read; any suggestion is welcome.
